cards.title: My best shot / Biggie Smalls in a graveyard

item.title: Michael Lavine's best shot: Biggie Smalls in a graveyard
item.trailText: ‘I took this up a hill in an area called Tombs of the Unknown Soldiers. Biggie was dead six weeks later’
item.standFirst: ‘I took this up a hill in an area called Tombs of the Unknown Soldiers. Biggie was dead six weeks later’
item.body:
When I first met Biggie Smalls (aka the Notorious BIG), I thought, “He’s going to rip my head off,” but he was the nicest guy you would ever want to meet. So friendly, with the softest handshake.

In the early 90s, I was an indie-rock photographer. I worked with Nirvana, Sonic Youth and the Beastie Boys. But then I started getting hired by hip-hop artists – they wanted me because I made them look like rock stars. I’m a grunge guy, not a hip-hop guy, though, and I did not fit into their world.

Everyone wanted to be shotpointing a gun at the lens. I had to ask the art directors to pull the bullets out of them so they wouldn’t shoot me by accident.

I never saw Biggie with a gun though. I was hired to shoot his second album, Life After Death. The concept was very overt. The suit was made to look like an undertaker’s and they wante him in a graveyard. It was in the middle of the east coast-west coast feud and a lot of people were getting shot. Tupac had already been killed. They were turning up the drama with this album.

The shoot took place in New York near Jackie Robinson Highway. Biggie was popular, but he wasn’t a legend yet. Still, it was the biggest job I’d ever had. I hired tonnes of speciality cameras and fancy lenses. The first shot we did became the album cover – Biggie standing in front of a hearse with the licence plate changed to B.I.G. When everything was in place, I asked my assistant to pass me my wide-angled lens. It wasn’t there. We searched everywhere, but the whole lot was gone: $15,000 of equipment. It must have been lifted while we were loading it into the van. I was nearly sick. I didn’t have time to think about what had happened, I just had to work through until the next break, when I sat in the graveyard on the phone to the insurance company.

I took this up a hill in an area called Tombs of the Unknown Soldiers. It was a real effort getting Biggie up there. He had a huge entourage – multiple SUVs filled with bodyguards, pot smoke billowing out of the windows.

I was hired by his manager Puffy – which is what he called himself before he became P Diddy. The guy was a real mastermind – he was the brains behind Bad Boy Records and the whole east-coast hip-hop movement. But he was also a jerk, and really difficult to deal with.

P Diddy was a real mastermind. But he was also a jerk, and really difficult to deal with.

At one point, we were looking for another location. The graveyard was so big, you had to drive around it. Puffy got in the front seat; Biggie got in the back. An Elvis song came on the CD: Suspicious Minds. Puffy went off: “What the hell is this crap?!” Then Biggie’s voice came from the back: “Man … chill out. Elvis was cool.”

We curved up the hill and parked and Biggie got out of the car with his cane and hobbled to the edge of the tombstones. He had a lot of physical ailments – he walked slow and heavy, and had this wandering left eye, which really infects this image.

I wanted the whole shot lined up with tombstones; no other distractions. The way that he is turned away from them is a symbol of defiance – a powerful stance that says: “You can’t touch me.”

Biggie died six weeks later. He was gunned down in Los Angeles. Nobody ever proved who shot him.

All these years later it’s still the most powerful image I have. The image of a young black man in a graveyard is politically very powerful. It was a news story every day then, and it still is now.

CV

Born: San Francisco, 1963.

Studied: Parsons School of Design, New York.

Influences: Philippe Halsman, Robert Frank, Garry Winogrand, Diane Arbus.

Career high: “I just shot the campaign for the show Empire. It’s the biggest TV show ever.”

Career low: “The time I got arrested and missed my shoot with Deee-Lite for Interview magazine.”

Top tip: “Never give up, never lose your cool.”

cards.title: Obi the pygmy hippo takes his first dip in the big pool
cards.rawTitle: Obi the pygmy hippo takes his first dip in the big pool

item.title: Obi the pygmy hippo takes his first dip in the big pool
item.trailText: Melbourne zoo's director, Kevin Tanner, talks about Obi, the male pygmy hippopotamus calf, who appeared in public this week to join his mother, Petre, for the first time at the zoo's big pool
item.standFirst: Melbourne zoo's director, Kevin Tanner, talks about Obi, the male pygmy hippopotamus calf, who appeared in public this week to join his mother, Petre, for the first time at the zoo's big pool. Obi was born on 27 May, the first of the endangered species born there since 1981

stillImage.caption: Obi, a male Pygmy Hippo calf, is seen inside its enclosure at the Melbourne Zoo, in Melbourne, Australia, 18 June 2015. EPA/TRACEY NEARMY  Photograph: TRACEY NEARMY/AAP Photograph: TRACEY NEARMY/AAP

cards.title: Tesco shoppers scramble on floor for discounted meat - video
cards.rawTitle: Tesco shoppers scramble on floor for discounted meat

item.title: Tesco shoppers scramble on floor for discounted meat
item.trailText: Shoppers at a Northampton Tesco are filmed pushing and shoving each other over discounted meat
item.standFirst: Shoppers at a Northampton Tesco are filmed pushing and shoving each other over discounted meat. In the video, filmed by Johnny Lester on Monday night, customers at the Tesco Extra store in the Weston Favell shopping centre are told several times by staff to 'move back', before converging on the discounted goods, with some taking to the floor of the supermarket. Onlookers are heard describing their actions as 'disgusting'

cards.title: Paris / Where street basketball meets hip-hop

item.title: Paris: where street basketball meets hip-hop
item.trailText: Quai 54 is the biggest street basketball championship in Europe, played in the centre of Paris against a backdrop of the Champs-Élysées and the Eiffel Tower
item.standFirst:
Quai 54 is the biggest street basketball championship in Europe, played in the centre of Paris against a backdrop of the Champs-Élysées and the Eiffel Tower. Iman Amrani had courtside access to the event and went to explore the relationship between basketball and hip-hop with French artists and dancers including Les Twins, Dosseh, Sadek and Joke

• WARNING: explicit lyrics (in French)
item.byline: Max Whittle, Iman Amrani and Juliet Riddell

item.title: Black Dog Project
item.trailText: Black Dog Project by Fred Levy – in pictures
item.standFirst: Fred Levy first heard about “black dog syndrome” in 2013 in a conversation at a dog park. It is a disputed theory that states that black dogs are the last to get adopted at shelters, perhaps because of superstition or a perception that they are aggressive. The idea inspired Levy to begin his Black Dog Project on their behalf. The dogs Levy photographed came from owners he recruited through his Facebook page. He had also started working with abandoned dogs referred to him by shelters – sharing their photos online in search of permanent homes. They are difficult to photograph well. A book of the project is due out later this year

displayImages.caption: Kenai ‘One of my first black dogs for the project. She is a beautiful German Shepherd. I’m very happy to find out that she is expecting puppies soon. She’s a beautiful dog who is very attached to the son of the owner. I find that GSD’s can be wonderful companions to the children (of all ages) of the family. I’m looking forward to seeing the puppies’

cards.title: Photo highlights of the day / Waterloo and wakeboarding

item.title: Photo highlights of the day: Waterloo and wakeboarding in Amsterdam
item.trailText: Rain in Manchester and Beijing, a baby undulate ray, and a wakeboarder jumps a canal boat in Amsterdam
item.standFirst: The Guardian’s picture editors bring you a selection of the best photographs from around the world, from Ascot to rain in Manchester and Beijing, a baby undulate ray, and a wakeboarder jumping a canal boat in Amsterdam

displayImages.caption: Ascot, UK Racegoer Tracy Rose arrives at Ascot for the annual racing event Photograph: Toby Melville/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Ascot, UK Racegoer Tracy Rose arrives at Ascot for the annual racing event

displayImages.caption: London, UK Chris Evans leaves the BBC Radio studios in his vintage Aston Martin, after he was announced as the new Top Gear presenter. He had long been tipped to take over after Jeremy Clarkson was sacked for punching one of the show’s producers in a row over dinner Photograph: John Stillwell/PA

displayImages.caption: Yogyakarta, Indonesia An Indonesian Muslim announces the beginning of the holy month of Ramadan. Amateur astronomers all over the south-east Asian country looked up at the night sky through telescopes for the crescent moon in a practice known as a Rukyatul Hilal. The sighting marked the beginning of the month when Muslims fast between dawn and sunset Photograph: Sijori Images/Barcroft India

Around 5,000 historical re-enactors from around the world will take part in three days of events to mark the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo which saw the overthrow of Napoleon Bonaparte Photograph: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images

image.caption: North Sumatra, Indonesia Farmers pause from their work as Mount Sinabung spews pyroclastic smoke, seen from Tiga Kicat village. According the National Disaster Mitigation Agency, more than 10,000 villagers have fled their homes since the authorities raised the alert status Photograph: Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images
image.altText: North Sumatra, Indonesia Farmers pause from their work as Mount Sinabung spews pyroclastic smoke, seen from Tiga Kicat village. According The National Disaster Mitigation Agency, more than 10,000 villagers have fled their homes since the authorities raised the alert status of Mount Sinabung erupting to the highest level

image.caption: Yogyakarta, Indonesia An Indonesian Muslim announces the beginning of the holy month of Ramadan. Amateur astronomers all over the south-east Asian country looked up at the night sky through telescopes for the crescent moon in a practice known as a Rukyatul Hilal. The sighting marked the beginning of the month when Muslims fast between dawn and sunset Photograph: Sijori Images/Barcroft India
image.altText: An Indonesian Muslim announces the beginning of the holy month of Ramadan
image.cleanCaption: Yogyakarta, Indonesia An Indonesian Muslim announces the beginning of the holy month of Ramadan. cards.title: Australia television host Samantha Armytage bathes in cockroaches
cards.rawTitle: Australia television host Samantha Armytage bathes in cockroaches

item.title: Breakfast television host Samantha Armytage bathes in cockroaches
item.trailText: Sunrise host Samantha Armytage faces one of her biggest fears by agreeing to be covered in thousands of cockroaches while lying in a oblong crate on Thursday morning's show
item.standFirst: Sunrise host Samantha Armytage faces one of her biggest fears by agreeing to be covered in thousands of cockroaches while lying in a oblong crate on Thursday morning's show. The only protection afforded her is a thin paper suit and goggles. On Wednesday her co-host, David Koch, faced his fear of spiders in a similar fashion
